content: The camp at Morristown is miserable. Soldiers' feet wrapped in rags. I'm sewing what I can but there's never enough cloth. George looks exhausted.
historicalContext: Martha Washington regularly joined George at winter camps, organizing sewing circles to make clothes for soldiers.

content: Third horseshoe I've made today that cracked. Bad iron. Everything is bad iron now. The good stuff goes to the army.
Everyone in the cafe talking about the Americans again. Exciting for them I suppose. I still have to be up at 3am to start the bread.
Cherry blossoms starting. The fish are biting well. My daughter asked why the sky is blue today. I told her to ask her mother because I don't know.
Letter from home. Ma says the cow had twins. Pa's gout is worse. My sister is engaged to the Miller boy. Feel like I'm missing everything.
Humidity is unbearable. The tea leaves need constant watching or they'll mold. My assistant fell asleep. Can't even be angry, I almost did too.
Congress left the city. Half my neighbors left too. We're staying. Where would we even go? The baby is too small to travel.
historicalContext: Congress fled Philadelphia as British forces approached. The British occupied the city from September 1777 to June 1778.

content: Philadelphia is quite comfortable actually. Good beds, decent food. The locals glare at us but at least it's not another forest camp. I'll take it.
Built a hut today. Twelve men will sleep in it. The floor is frozen mud. Someone stole my other sock while I was working. War is glamorous.
historicalContext: Valley Forge winter quarters. Soldiers built over 1,000 log huts. Disease and supply shortages killed nearly 2,000 men.

content: Ate fire cake again. Flour and water cooked on a rock. I used to complain about my mother's cooking. I would do unspeakable things for her worst meal right now.
accuracyNote: Fire cake was a documented staple at Valley Forge.
historicalContext: Fire cake - flour and water cooked on hot stones - was the main food for many soldiers during Valley Forge.

content: New Year preparations. My mother is making dumplings. I should be helping but the silk order is late and the merchant will be angry. Priorities.
The Prussian drill master arrived. Baron von Steuben. He swears in German, then French, then has someone translate the swears to English. The men love it.
historicalContext: Baron von Steuben arrived at Valley Forge and began training the Continental Army. He famously used colorful language in multiple languages.

content: Spring thaw. Everything is mud. The palace gardens look tragic. I'm told the roads are impassable. Good. Fewer visitors.
Treaty signed with France. Finally. My French is still terrible but they pretend not to notice. Very polite people. Now if only my gout would improve.
historicalContext: France officially recognized American independence and signed treaties of alliance and commerce in February 1778, ratified by Congress in May.

content: Monsoon started early. The roof leaks in three new places. Fixed one, two more appeared. This is metaphor for life, probably.
The British left! Just... left. Our neighbors are coming back. The streets feel different somehow. Quieter. Or maybe I'm different.
historicalContext: British forces evacuated Philadelphia in June 1778 after France entered the war, consolidating their forces in New York.

content: Summer festival preparations. Three new songs to learn by next week. My shamisen string broke during practice. Why does everything break before festivals?
Too hot to work. Too hot to think. The coffee is too hot. I am too hot. Everyone is too hot. This is known.
Third winter of the war. At least we have actual supplies this time. Real shoes. I keep looking at them. Just... looking at shoes. War changes you.
Flour prices again. Every month higher. The customers blame me like I'm setting the prices. I'm just the one who wakes up at 3am to turn it into bread.
historicalContext: Bread prices in France were rising due to poor harvests and war expenditures, contributing to the conditions that would lead to the French Revolution.

content: Good rain this week. The yams are growing well. My eldest asked when he can have his own plot. I told him when he can wake before sunrise without being dragged.
Festival of San Juan. Sold all my tamales by noon. My feet hurt. My back hurts. My hands hurt. But we eat well tonight. This is the trade.
Captured a British ship. The Serapis. My own ship was sinking as we did it. They asked if I was surrendering. I was not. We won. Barely. My coat is ruined.
historicalContext: The Battle of Flamborough Head. John Paul Jones allegedly replied 'I have not yet begun to fight!' when asked to surrender the sinking Bonhomme Richard.

content: Winter longer than last year. Or maybe it just feels longer. The master wants more wood chopped. There is always more wood to chop.
Training the new recruits. They complain about everything. I remember complaining. Now I'm the one telling them to stop complaining. Life is circular.
Congress passed me over for promotion. Again. Five generals junior to me got advanced. After everything I've done. After Saratoga. Fine. Fine.
historicalContext: Arnold felt consistently slighted by Congress despite his military successes. He began secret negotiations with the British in 1779.

content: Married Eliza Schuyler. She's far too good for me and I've told her so. She disagrees. I'll spend my life proving she's right. Starting tomorrow. Today we celebrate.
historicalContext: Alexander Hamilton married Elizabeth Schuyler on December 14, 1780.

content: New Year. Sixth year of the war. Some of the boys who started with me are dead. Some went home. Some of us are still here. Don't know why. Just are.
My son wants to be a poet instead of a merchant. I told him poets don't eat. He said they eat poetry. I said try eating poetry when you're forty. He left angry.
Moving through Virginia. The countryside is beautiful when it's not actively shooting at you. Greene keeps retreating then counterattacking. Exhausting man.
historicalContext: Cornwallis was pursuing American forces through the South in 1781. Nathanael Greene's strategy of retreat and counterattack wore down British forces.

content: The Dauphin is walking now. Running, really. Into everything. The nursemaids are exhausted. I'm exhausted. But his laugh. His little laugh makes it worth it.
historicalContext: Louis Joseph, the Dauphin, was born in 1781. Marie Antoinette was devoted to her children.

content: Daughter got married today. I didn't cry. I definitely didn't cry. There was just... something in my eye. For the whole ceremony. Both eyes actually.
Setting up at Yorktown. Good defensive position. Waiting for the navy. They'll come. They always come. The navy always comes.
historicalContext: Cornwallis fortified Yorktown expecting British naval support. The French fleet would instead arrive and trap his army.

content: French fleet has the Chesapeake. Cornwallis is trapped. We're marching south. After six years, this might be it. This might actually be it.
historicalContext: Washington learned the French fleet under de Grasse had defeated the British navy and sealed off the Chesapeake, trapping Cornwallis.

content: The siege works are almost complete. Cornwallis knows it's over. He knows. We all know. Strange feeling, the end of something this big.
historicalContext: The siege of Yorktown was nearing its conclusion. French and American forces had surrounded the British.

content: People keep asking when the war will officially end. I keep making horseshoes. Someone still needs horseshoes whether there's a war or not.
Parliament wants to recognize American independence. Lose the colonies, they say. Just like that. I wanted to keep them. For their own good, really.
historicalContext: After Yorktown, Parliament moved toward ending the war. Lord North's government fell and peace negotiations began.

content: Negotiating peace in Paris. Franklin is charming everyone. Jay is being difficult about boundaries. I'm making lists. We all contribute what we can.
historicalContext: Adams, Franklin, and Jay negotiated the Treaty of Paris. Adams focused on fishing rights, Jay on boundaries.

content: Treaty signed. War's over. Going home. Can't quite believe it. Been a soldier so long, not sure I remember how to be anything else.
historicalContext: Congress ratified the preliminary peace treaty in April 1783. Soldiers began mustering out of the Continental Army.

content: My brother came home today. Seven years he was gone. He looks older. We all look older. The children barely recognized him. He cried. We all cried.
Saying farewell to my officers at Fraunces Tavern. Tried to speak. Couldn't get the words out. Embraced each one. These men... these extraordinary men.
historicalContext: Washington's emotional farewell to his officers at Fraunces Tavern in New York is well documented. He reportedly could barely speak.

content: Resigned my commission to Congress today. Gave back the power. Going home to Martha. To Mount Vernon. To farming. To peace. Finally, peace.
historicalContext: Washington resigned his military commission and returned to private life, stunning the world. King George III said it made him 'the greatest man in the world.'
